poem:
"Insure your Ever(house)dream"

winged policy,how
we spin silkthreads for yonder nest?
(own or freehold,tenant or guest)
bricked words in your lease, i best

"what insures?" whispers
insurer to the comparison's quest

contents or capitals,
we don the same vest
a roof is but a jest,

Only love,
in your undying breast,
outlasts the rest.
prompt: You are the poet E.E. Cummings. You woke up this morning feeling optimistic. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Home insurance: how to get the best and cheapest UK policy Work out what you need If you own your property, you will need to cover the building and its contents – unless it is a leasehold flat and the freeholder insures the block. This should be spelled out in your lease. If you are a tenant, you will only need contents insurance. One of the first questions an insurer or comparison website will ask". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: Home insurance: how to get the best and cheapest UK policy Work out what you need If you own your property, you will need to cover the building and its contents – unless it is a leasehold flat and the freeholder insures the block. This should be spelled out in your lease. If you are a tenant, you will only need contents insurance. One of the first questions an insurer or comparison website will ask
